title: In The Princess Bride, why was the grandson in bed? Was he sick because he did not seem to be? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the book, Goldman pretends he is telling something that actually happened to him. But it is fictional. The family he has in the book is not the family he had in real life. In the book, he remembers that when he was a child, he had a fever that is so high, he got delusional about trying to listen to some baseball game on the radio, even though he had been told there was no game that day. In the book, Goldman, as a kid, isn't interested in books, only sports. His father, an immigrant and very old country, decides to entertain his bedridden son by reading him “THE PRINCESS BRIDE,” which is the kid's first introduction to romantic fantasy. This was too much backstory for a film, so they made the kid contemporary. They still wanted to keep the reader an old country immigrant, so they made him a grandfather. A father would not have been old fashioned enough at the time the film was made. But the kid is still sick Not as sick in the film as he was in the book. Read the book. The film is great, but the book is better.

The Grandson is sick in bed. He coughs at the start of the film. Then the Grandfather says both: “Hey! How’s the sickie? Heh?” And later, “It was the book my father used to read to me when I was sick, and I used to read it to your father, and today, I'm gonna read it to you.” So it’s heavily implied that the Grandson is sick but we’re not told what illness he has. The Grandson also does cough before the Grandfather comes in, but doesn’t keep coughing through the film, though to be fair that would be really distracting and might cause us to throw popcorn at the screen. In the book, there’s no Grandson, just a disconnected father-son pair, so we can’t rely on that to give us answers, and the screenplay doesn’t tell us. There’s an interesting thought here: Grief, Fathers, and The Princess Bride on whether the Father is in fact dead, and the Grandfather is attempting to help the Grandson through his grief. I don’t think so, but it’s an interesting thought.
